proposals.reasoning: The discussion has generally converged on using Diana as a relatively safe anchor for Quest 1. I previously expressed a slight preference for pairing Diana with Bob rather than Alice to avoid auto-clearing Alice off a single successful 2-player mission. Choosing Bob+Diana is consistent with that logic: it gives us early information on two players who are both presenting as steady, minimizes drama, and avoids prematurely locking in trust on Alice based solely on an opening pass.

votes.comment: I still prefer starting with Alice+Diana as the lowest-assumption test; I’m not convinced the argument about avoiding an early soft-clear on Alice outweighs putting the proposer onto the first mission.
I’m on the team, and an early 2-player mission with Diana is a good low-risk info-gathering setup.
As evil, I want my teammate on the first mission to create early ambiguity and potential sabotage.
I like being on the first mission as a relatively safe anchor, and this pair gives us early info on Bob without auto-clearing Alice off a single pass.
Consistent with my stated preference for Diana+Bob as an early low-drama info team; nothing yet to justify opposing it.

discussion.content: Early missions are mostly about information, so I’d rather start with a low-drama, low-suspicion pair—something like me and Diana feels like a reasonable opening test.
Alice+Diana is fine as an opening info-gathering pair, but I’d also be comfortable with something like Diana+me so at least one person can directly vouch for the other afterward.
Diana feels like the safest anchor right now, so I’d be happy with either Alice+Diana or Diana+me as a low-drama first test.

I’m fine being on Q1, but we shouldn’t over-interpret a single clean or failed 2-person mission. Between Alice+me and Bob+me, I slightly prefer Alice this early, just so we’re not auto-trusting Bob/Charlie if it passes.

I like keeping Diana as the anchor, but I slightly prefer Diana+Bob over Diana+Alice so we don’t end up auto-clearing Alice too quickly off a single pass. If everyone’s more comfortable with Alice+Diana, I’d want us to treat that result as very soft info, not a hard trust.

proposals.reasoning: We get Diana back on as our only player with a successful mission so far, but avoid re-using the exact Bob+Diana pair from Mission 1 so we don’t over-clear that combo too quickly. Adding both me (Alice) and Eve lets us test two entirely new players alongside Diana, which spreads information efficiently without doubling down on anyone from the first mission besides her. Leaving Bob and Charlie both off this time also means we can compare how a Diana-led team performs without Bob, and still have plenty of options for future missions depending on this result.

votes.comment: Keeps our only previously successful member while testing two new players and avoids repeating the Bob+Diana pair too early, giving good information if it passes or fails.
I don’t love a 3-player team that excludes both Bob and Charlie at once; feels like we’re dodging information on two people simultaneously instead of testing at least one of them alongside Diana.
I’d prefer a team that includes me so I can start generating my own mission info, and I’m wary of leaving both Bob and me off back-to-back teams this early.
This matches the spread I asked for (me + one of Bob/Eve + one of Alice/Charlie), gives good info without over-clearing the Bob+Diana pair.
Matches what I advocated: keep provisional-good Diana, add myself plus a new player (Alice) and avoid re-using the Bob+Diana pair too quickly.

discussion.content: Given the first mission, I’m inclined to trust Diana for now, but I’d prefer we mix it up a bit rather than re-using the same pair, so maybe build a team around Diana plus two people who haven’t gone yet.
I wouldn’t clear either me or Diana just off that first success yet, but I do like keeping Diana on this team and adding one of Alice/Charlie so we’re not just repeating the same exact pair.

I’m okay giving Diana provisional trust after that first mission, so I’d like to see her stay on. Maybe something like Diana + me + either Alice or Eve, so we’re not overusing the same combinations too early.

I’m fine being treated as provisional-good for now, but I don’t want us to over-trust that first mission, so I’d like a team of me plus exactly one of Bob/Eve and then one of Alice/Charlie to start spreading information.
I’m good keeping Diana on after the first mission, but I’d rather not lock in the Bob+Diana pair yet, so I like a team of Diana + me + one of Alice/Charlie to start spreading info.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Bob and Diana was clean, and Diana was also on the successful three-person team in Mission 2. With the score already at 2–0, the lowest-risk option is to rerun the only proven 2-player combo rather than introduce new, untested pairs on a potential match point for good.

votes.comment: I don’t think Bob+Diana are truly ‘proven’ from a single 2-player success—an evil can easily pass early. At 2–0 we can afford a safer-feeling test like reusing overlap between both clean teams (e.g. me+Diana) rather than hard-locking this pair on match point.
As proposed member and evil, I want this to go through so I have a chance to fail the mission and prevent good from winning 3–0.
This is the lowest-variance team on match point and matches what I already argued for (repeating the proven Bob+Diana pair from Mission 1).
Bob+Diana is the only proven 2-player combo; at 2–0 this is lowest risk, and even a fail would clearly out Bob while still leaving good in a winnable spot.
On match point, rerunning the only proven 2-player combo (Bob + Diana) is the lowest-risk line; if it somehow fails, the info is very clean, and if it passes we win.

discussion.content: Since we’re already up 2–0, I’d rather play it safe and pick from the trio that just gave us a clean Mission 2. Any two of Alice/Diana/Eve feels like the lowest-risk combo right now.

Given that Mission 1 with me and Diana was clean, I’d lean toward repeating that pair as the simplest, lowest-variance option. If people really want to mix it up, I’d still keep Diana and swap the second slot with someone we already trust from Mission 2.
Given we’re on match point, I’d stick with the lowest-variance option: Bob + Diana already proved clean on Mission 1, so re-running that pair feels safer than introducing a new combo now.
Given both Mission 1 (Bob + me) and Mission 2 (Alice + me + Eve) were clean, I think I’m a pretty safe anchor, and the lowest-risk play on match point is just to rerun Bob + me for this one.
I’m fine leaning into the lowest-variance line here and sending Bob + Diana again—if that somehow fails, we get a very clear info hit, and if it passes we just win.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s clean info strongly points to Alice and Eve as the safest anchors, while the Bob–Diana pair is now contaminated by the Mission 3 fail and doesn’t help us distinguish which one is bad. This team reuses the trusted Alice–Eve core, keeps both Bob and Diana off after their failed pairing, and only introduces a single new variable in me rather than re‑running any suspicious combo.

votes.comment: I don’t like introducing an untested Charlie when we already have a fully clean 3-player team from Mission 2; I’d rather stick with Alice–Diana–Eve than gamble here.
Charlie is on the team and a fail here is our best shot to tie the score and reach a decisive Mission 5.
Keeps the suspicious Bob–Diana pair off the mission and reuses the trusted Alice–Eve core, with me as the only new variable.

I know I’m good, so the Mission 3 fail makes Bob the clear suspect. The remaining evil is among Alice/Charlie/Eve, and Charlie is the only completely untested one. It’s safer to reuse the proven-successful Alice–Diana–Eve trio than to introduce Charlie here.

Given the mission history and constraints, Bob is statistically the likeliest evil, Alice the least. This team anchors on the clean Alice–Eve core from Mission 2 and keeps Bob off, which is as reasonable a risk profile as we can get now.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 was a clean three-person team, I’d really like to see something like Alice–Diana–Eve again rather than re-using the Bob/Diana pair that just produced the fail. It feels safer to lean on the only fully successful 3-player combo we’ve seen so far.

I get why people are side‑eyeing the Bob/Diana pair after that fail, but remember a single fail doesn’t tell you which of us (if either) is bad. If we’re playing it safe off the info we have, I’d rather see something like Alice–Eve plus one of Bob/Diana than re‑running the exact pair that just burned us.

Given Diana’s been on every single team including the one that just failed, I’m a lot more nervous about her than anyone else right now. I’d rather see something like Alice–Eve–Charlie as a clean-looking trio that avoids the Bob/Diana tangle altogether.

Mission 2 is our best piece of info so far, and it was clean, so I’m most comfortable re‑using Alice–Diana–Eve and leaving Bob off after the Bob/Diana fail rather than introducing an untested Charlie right now.
From my perspective, Mission 2 makes Alice and I look pretty solid, and the Bob/Diana pair is now contaminated, so the safest play is Alice–Eve–Charlie and we keep both Bob and Diana off this one.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with Alice–Diana–Eve is the only 3-player team that has actually produced a success, while every team involving the Bob–Diana pair or the Alice–Charlie–Eve trio has now produced a fail. Mission 3 proves exactly one of Bob/Diana is evil; since I know I’m good, that points to Bob as the more likely evil. Mission 4’s fail then means the other evil is among {Alice, Charlie, Eve}. Eve’s deduction that the remaining evil must be in {Alice, Charlie} is exactly what a good player in her seat would conclude, which makes her more likely good and pushes suspicion toward Charlie. That leaves Bob and Charlie as the likeliest evil pair, making Alice–Diana–Eve the most plausible all-good team and the best final mission choice.

votes.comment: It’s the only 3-player combo that’s already proven clean, and it keeps the suspicious Bob/Diana pairing from Mission 3 broken while avoiding the Alice–Charlie–Eve trio that just failed.
Mission 3 showed exactly one of me/Diana is evil; I still don’t want Diana auto-cleared and put back on here when we could instead keep both of us off and use Alice–Eve–Charlie.

Mission 3 shows one of Bob/Diana is evil and we haven’t seen Diana on a failing 3-player team yet, so I’m not comfortable trusting that earlier clean as conclusive; I’d rather see a team that avoids both the Bob/Diana pair and reuses as few overlaps as possible.

From my perspective Bob must be evil from Mission 3, and comparing worlds makes Bob+Charlie the most consistent evil pair (Charlie’s team suggestions are bad if he’s good but sensible if he’s evil). That leaves Alice–Diana–Eve as the most likely all-good team, so I want this mission to go.

From Mission 3 exactly one of Bob/Diana is evil; from Mission 4 at least one of Alice/Charlie is evil and I know I’m good. In all consistent worlds, the evil pair is one of {Bob,Diana} plus one of {Alice,Charlie}, so Alice–Diana–Eve always includes exactly one evil and cannot be a fully good team.

proposals.reasoning: We know exactly one of Bob or Diana is evil from Mission 3, and at least one of Alice or Charlie is evil from Mission 4 (since I know I am good). The only 3-player team that has previously succeeded is Alice–Diana–Eve on Mission 2, with zero fails. Any team that includes both Alice and Charlie must contain at least one confirmed suspect and so is very likely compromised. Any team including both Bob and Diana is guaranteed to include exactly one of the known suspects from Mission 3. Reusing the previously clean Alice–Diana–Eve team avoids the guaranteed-suspect pair (Bob+Diana together and Alice+Charlie together) while sticking with the only fully successful 3-player combination we have seen.

votes.comment: This is the only 3-player combo that’s already proven clean on a mission, so it’s our safest option for the last quest.
I don’t want to approve a team that looks fully clean when we need a chance for evil to sabotage the final mission.
I still don’t want Diana on the final team after she was on both the early successes and the failed Mission 3; I’d rather see a team like Alice–Eve–me that keeps both Bob and Diana off.

From Mission 3 I know I’m good, so Bob must be the spy there. Mission 4 then has exactly one spy among {Alice, Charlie, Eve}. The first ADE proposal was rejected 3–2, likely by Bob, Charlie, and Eve. If Eve were evil, ADE would still contain exactly one spy and be acceptable for evil; the strong coordinated push away from ADE instead points to Bob+Charlie as the evil pair, making Alice–Diana–Eve all good.

Given one evil in {Bob,Diana} and one in {Alice,Charlie}, Bob’s and Charlie’s preferences line up better with an evil agenda. That makes Alice and Diana more likely good, so repeating the previously clean Alice–Diana–Eve team is our best shot.

discussion.content: Given the results so far, the only fully clean combo we’ve seen on a 3-player team is Alice–Diana–Eve on Mission 2, so I’d feel best about just repeating that team for the last quest.

If we assume the fail on 3 came from either me or Diana, I really don’t like putting her straight back on after being the common factor in almost every team. I’d rather see something like you, Eve, and Charlie, keeping both me and Diana off this last mission.

I’m really uneasy with putting Diana back on after she was on both the clean early teams and the later fail, so I’d rather avoid her here. Between Alice/Eve/Charlie or Alice/Eve/Bob, I slightly prefer keeping both Bob and Diana off and going Alice–Eve–Charlie.

Given Mission 3 proves exactly one of Bob/Diana is evil and I was also on the fully clean 3-person team in Mission 2, I think it’s far more likely Bob is the problem than me. Mission 4 then points to the remaining evil being in {Alice, Charlie, Eve}, and since Alice–Diana–Eve was already clean, I’m most comfortable repeating that team.

From Mission 3 we know exactly one of Bob/Diana is evil, and from Mission 4 I know the other evil is in {Alice, Charlie}, so I’d rather keep both Bob and Diana off and go with Alice–Charlie–me for the final team.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Eve as Merlin: she consistently pushed the “correct”-looking good teams (especially Alice–Eve–Charlie) and very cleanly articulated the Bob/Diana contamination story without ever over-committing to a specific second evil until late, which feels like someone steering with extra info but trying not to show it. Alice reads more like a cautious, vanilla good following visible mission results, and Diana’s hyper-defensiveness around her own inclusion feels more like a suspected-but-not-informed power role than someone quietly coordinating around hidden knowledge.

I’m mostly with Bob that Eve is the best Merlin hit: she consistently framed the “information story” in a way that lined up eerily well with the real alignment spread, especially her comfort with Alice–Eve–Charlie as the endgame “safe” trio and her early push to keep Bob/Diana treated as a poisoned pair without ever hard-clearing me. Alice feels more like a cautious scanner just following mission outcomes, and Diana’s tone reads like someone under suspicion trying to argue herself towny, not like someone calmly piloting with perfect info.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Eve consistently pushed toward the actually-good team configurations—especially Alice–Eve–Charlie at the end—and framed the Bob/Diana pair as “contaminated” very early in a way that matches the real alignment. Her arguments track more like someone with hidden knowledge carefully avoiding hard-clears than like a vanilla good just reacting to mission results, whereas Alice and Diana both read as more visibly confused and reactive.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed information fairly well this game, especially by not over-clearing Diana and Eve too early while still pushing missions toward mostly good teams. I could improve by seeding more plausible suspicion on myself as a regular good player, since my consistent presence on successful teams and resistance to some evil-leaning proposals probably contributed to Eve being a plausible Merlin candidate rather than fully muddying the waters.

player_observations.Bob: Aggressive and opportunistic, willing to take the risky early fail on Mission 3 and then lean on social persuasion rather than mechanical safety. He seemed comfortable driving the narrative, which makes him dangerous in later games as either alignment.
player_observations.Charlie: More low-key and reactive, blending into discussions instead of strongly leading them, which let him avoid heavy scrutiny even after Mission 4 failed under his leadership. This quieter approach works well for evil but may cause trust issues when he’s actually good.
player_observations.Diana: Played very straightforwardly, voting and speaking in ways that matched a typical cautious good player, which made it easier to trust her after the pattern of mission results emerged. She didn’t push hard theories but supported reasonable teams reliably.
player_observations.Eve: Appeared consistently logical and was often in the center of team discussions as an anchor of apparent reasonableness, which made her a natural Merlin suspect in the assassination phase. Her willingness to take leadership and accept responsibility for critical missions added to her perceived informational authority.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed to get a crucial fail on Mission 3 without drawing too much immediate heat, and I helped push through a bad team on Mission 4, keeping evil in contention. However, I misread Merlin’s signal density and over-weighted Eve’s late-game confidence, causing a wrong assassination; I need to track early subtle guidance from Merlin more carefully and cross-check it against voting patterns instead of focusing so much on endgame table talk.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled Merlin game, giving just enough guidance to get good teams approved (especially on Missions 2 and 5) without obviously hard-clearing anyone; her calm consistency and non-flashy steering made her look like generic ‘solid good’ rather than a power role.
player_observations.Charlie: Did solid, low-profile evil work by participating in the Mission 4 fail without making it feel like a huge information event, blending his voting and table talk well enough that suspicion stayed diffuse rather than focused on him.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally good by accepting some risk on teams and not forcing herself into every mission, which made her successful participation on Missions 1, 2, and 5 look like organic trust rather than coordinated signaling.
player_observations.Eve: Showed confident leadership and table presence, especially as a frequent team member and final leader, which made her look like a likely information hub and drew my Merlin read; her assertiveness without being over-defensive was convincing enough to mislead my assassination.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated the Mission 3 and 4 fails in a way that kept suspicion somewhat distributed, especially by not overpushing for early sabotages and blending in with team logic. However, I could have done more to subtly steer the assassin away from Eve and toward Alice by questioning Alice’s accurate reads more aggressively and creating stronger, earlier narratives that painted her as cautious-good rather than secretly well-informed.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled and measured Merlin game, feeding information gradually and avoiding obvious hard-pushes that would mark her as a power role. Her team selections were quietly accurate, which in hindsight should have been a bigger red flag than Eve’s more visible leadership.
player_observations.Bob: As assassin, Bob committed to the Eve narrative, suggesting he was reading surface-level behavior and visible influence more than subtle information-control. He stayed reasonably low-key during missions but could be nudged in his suspicions, which made him somewhat steerable but also capable of locking into a wrong-but-confident guess.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as straightforward and consistent, which made her look solidly good and not particularly controversial in team discussions. Her presence on both the early success and the failed Mission 3 created some ambiguity, but she didn’t overdefend herself, which actually helped her credibility.
player_observations.Eve: Eve’s visible leadership and involvement in key missions made her an attractive candidate for the assassin, especially since she looked proactive and influential. She projected a confident, central-good vibe that unintentionally drew the night-kill attention away from the more subtly correct Merlin signals from Alice.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently trustworthy on missions and helped secure three clean successes, which made it easier for Merlin and the rest of the team to read me as good. I could have pushed harder on the logic after Mission 3 and 4 fails to narrow down the evil team earlier and to better shield Alice from suspicion going into the final mission and assassination.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very calm and controlled Merlin game, guiding team choices toward clean missions without drawing too much heat; her inclusion patterns were subtly pro-good without being obvious. Even after the Mission 4 fail, she didn’t overdefend herself, which probably helped the assassin misfire on Eve.
player_observations.Bob: Took advantage of his early trust from Mission 1 to later sneak in the fail on Mission 3, suggesting he’s comfortable playing a longer con rather than being aggressively suspicious. His assassination on Eve shows he was fairly convinced by surface-level mission history and maybe underestimated how low-key Alice’s Merlin game was.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and only directly contributed to a single failing mission on Team 4, which suggests a more passive evil style relying on others’ social reads and confusion. He didn’t strongly push misdirecting narratives, which made him less obviously evil but also less influential overall.
player_observations.Eve: As a frequent team member and final mission leader, she projected a generally trustworthy, cooperative vibe and made solid team choices in Missions 1 and 5. The assassin’s final guess on her as Merlin shows she appeared informed and confident enough in her reads that evil mistook her good play for a power role.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently village-leaning in tone and team choices, especially by backing Alice and Diana on key missions and proposing the winning team on Mission 5. I could improve by pushing harder on structured reasoning after Mission 3 and 4 fails, since I mostly relied on vibe reads rather than clearly narrowing down the evil pair, which might have helped misdirect the assassin even more.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very controlled, low-key Merlin game—gave just enough support to good teams (especially Missions 2 and 5) without being loud or over-directive, which helped avoid the assassin’s final guess.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in well early with a strong social presence and took advantage of the clean Mission 1 to build trust, but the fail on Mission 3 followed by his overall positioning made his alignment increasingly suspicious in retrospect.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar and let others drive the team discussions, which helped mask evil alignment for a while, but the failed Mission 4 with Alice and me on it created a lot of late-game doubt around that team slot.
player_observations.Diana: Came across as naturally trustworthy and consistent; being on both an early success (Mission 1) and the final success (Mission 5) reinforced a solid good image, and she didn’t overcomplicate the table with unnecessary speculation.
